Class Notationer

java.lang.Object
math.core.Notationer
public class Notationer extends Object
Manages the format and convertion between differents numeric notations. Intended to be used only as a stakeholder manager for its functions.

Provides comprehensive number formatting, validation, and conversion utilities for different numeric notations. This class handles conversion between scientific notation and standard form, manages thousands separators and decimal points, cleans non-numeric characters, and splits numbers into integer/decimal components.

Key Features:

  • Scientific Notation Expansion - Converts exponential format (1.23E4) to standard form (12300)
  • Number Validation and Cleaning - Removes invalid characters and normalizes number formats
  • Multi-Notation Support - Formats numbers using either decimal point (1,234.56) or comma (1.234,56) notation
  • Component Separation - Splits numbers into integer and decimal parts
  • Zero Trimming - Removes insignificant leading/trailing zeros
  • Thousands Formatting - Adds appropriate separators for readability

Use Cases:

  1. Normalizing user-input numbers with mixed formats
  2. Converting scientific notation for display purposes
  3. Formatting large numbers with proper thousands separators
  4. Preparing numbers for arithmetic operations by standardizing formats
  5. Cleaning malformed numeric strings from external sources
Notation Systems Supported:
SystemInteger SeparatorDecimal SeparatorExample
Decimal Point NotationComma (,)Period (.)1,234.56
Decimal Comma NotationPeriod (.)Comma (,)1.234,56

Usage Example:



		public class MyClass{

			private Notationer notationManager = new Notationer();

		}
Since:
v0.0.1

  • Method Details

    • isValidNumber

      public boolean isValidNumber(String number)
      Recieves a String parameter and validates if it is a real number.

      Usage Example 
      

			boolean isValid = this.notationManager.isValidNumber("1.234E-5");
      The return values will be isValid = true
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      boolean Returns either true if it is a valid number or false if it is not.
      Since:
      v0.0.6

    • Normalize

      public String[] Normalize(StringBuilder number)
      Recieves a number as a StringBuilder parameter and normalizes it to make it readable in case it is not on a standard notation.

      Usage Example 
      

			String[] parts = this.notationManager.validateAndNormalize(new StringBuilder(

				"1234.56"

			));
      The return values will be parts[0] = 1234 and parts[1] = 56
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a StringBuilder.
      Returns:
      String[] Returns a String array with the integer part and the decimal part of the number.
      Since:
      v0.0.6
      See Also:
      • expandScientificNotation(StringBuilder)
      • trimZeros(String)
      • cleanNonNumericCharacters(String, boolean)
      • splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts(String)

    • validateAndNormalize

      protected String[] validateAndNormalize(StringBuilder number)
      Recieves a number as a StringBuilder parameter, validates it to make sure it is infact a number and normalizes it to make it readable in case it is not on a standard notation.

      Usage Example 
      

			String[] parts = this.notationManager.validateAndNormalize(new StringBuilder(

				"1234.56"

			));
      The return values will be parts[0] = 1234 and parts[1] = 56
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a StringBuilder.
      Returns:
      String[] Returns a String array with the integer part and the decimal part of the number.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if StringBuilder number is either null or empty.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
      See Also:
      • expandScientificNotation(StringBuilder)
      • trimZeros(String)
      • cleanNonNumericCharacters(String, boolean)
      • splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts(String)

    • format

      protected String format(String integerPart, String decimalPart, boolean useDecimalPointNotation)
      Recieves a number as two String parameters, one representing the integer part and the other representing its decimal part and a boolean parameter that tells if the number uses decimal point notation. This parameter is true if it does.

      Usage Example 
      

			String n = this.notationManager.format("1234", "56");
      The return values will be either n = 1,234.56 in case the boolean useDecimalPointNotation parameter if true or n = 1.234,56 in case is false.
      Parameters:
      integerPart - Integer Part of a number as a String.
      decimalPart - Decimal Part of a number as a String.
      useDecimalPointNotation - Tells if it uses or not decimal point notation as a boolean.
      Returns:
      String Returns a number as a String with the specified notation declared on the boolean useDecimalPointNotation parameter.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
      See Also:
      • formatIntegerPart(StringBuilder, String, char)

    • expandScientificNotation

      protected StringBuilder expandScientificNotation(StringBuilder scientificNumber)
      Recieves a number as a StringBuilder parameter, validates it to make sure it is infact in scientific notation, if so it will return the number expanded, if not it will return itself.

      Usage Example 
      

			StringBuilder n = this.notationManager.expandScientificNotation(new StringBuilder(

				"1.23456E3"

			));
      The return values will be n = 1234.56
      Parameters:
      scientificNumber - Number in scientific notation as a StringBuilder.
      Returns:
      StringBuilder Returns a StringBuilder with the number expanded.
      Since:
      v0.0.1

    • cleanNonNumericCharacters

      protected StringBuilder cleanNonNumericCharacters(String number, boolean hasBeenValidated)
      Recieves a number as a String parameter, validates its back and front, and then removes every non numeric characters.

      Usage Example 
      

			StringBuilder n = this.notationManager.cleanNonNumericCharacters("--.012++", false);
      The return values will be parts[0] = 0.0123
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a String.
      hasBeenValidated - boolean parameter indicating if it has already been validated for a numberic format.
      Returns:
      StringBuilder Returns a StringBuilder number that is a full readable.
      Since:
      v0.0.1

    • splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts

      protected String[] splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts(String number)
      Recieves a number as a String parameter, validates if it has a decimal part, if not it will fills it with empty to make sure it always return a 2 length String array.

      Usage Example 
      

			String[] parts = this.notationManager.splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts("1234.56");
      The return values will be parts[0] = 1234 and parts[1] = 56
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      String[] Returns a String array with the integer and decimal part.
      Since:
      v0.0.1

    • trimZeros

      protected String trimZeros(String str)
      Recieves a number as a String parameter, validates if it has a decimal point to extend the regrex statement to not trim the zeros at the end if it is not a decimal number.

      Usage Example 
      

			String n = this.notationManager.trimZeros("00000001234.56000000000");
      The return values will be n = 1234.56
      Parameters:
      str - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      String Returns a String with the zeros trimed.
      Since:
      v0.0.1

    • formatIntegerPart

      protected void formatIntegerPart(StringBuilder formatted, String integerPart, char separator)
      Recieves a empty StringBuilder recipient parameter, the integer part of a number as a String and char separator.

      Usage Example 
      

			StringBuffer n = new StringBuilder();
			char separator = ',';

			this.notationManager.formatIntegerPart(n, "1234", separator);
      The new n value will be 1,234
      Parameters:
      formatted - Empty recipient as a StringBuilder.
      integerPart - Integer part of a number as a integerPart.
      separator - Separator as a char.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
